citation.text: "Genderqueer, also known as non-binary, is a catch-all category for gender identities that are not exclusively masculine or feminine-identities which are outside the gender binary and cisnormativity. Genderqueer people may express a combination of masculinity and femininity, or neither, in their gender expression." [1]
sourceList: Genderqueer. (2018, July 8). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Genderqueer&oldid=874316981)

citation.text: "Genderqueer, also known as non-binary, is a catch-all category for gender identities that are not exclusively masculine or feminine-identities which are outside the gender binary and cisnormativity. Genderqueer people may express a combination of masculinity and femininity, or neither, in their gender expression." [1]
sourceList: Genderqueer. (2018, July 8). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Genderqueer&oldid=874316981)

citation.text: "A person who is genderfluid prefers to remain flexible about their gender identity rather than committing to a single gender. They may fluctuate between genders or express multiple genders at the same time." [1]
sourceList: Genderqueer. (2018, July 8). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Genderqueer&oldid=874316981)
citation.imageSource: Genderfluidity Pride-Flag.svg. (2015, Feb 6). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Genderfluidity_Pride-Flag.svg&oldid=296300585)

citation.text: "The rainbow flag, commonly known as the gay pride flag or LGBT pride flag, is a symbol of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) pride and LGBT social movements... The colors reflect the diversity of the LGBT community, as the flag is often used as a symbol of gay pride during LGBT rights marches. While this use of the rainbow flag originated in Northern California’s San Francisco Bay Area, the flag is now used worldwide. Originally devised by San Francisco artist Gilbert Baker, the design has undergone several revisions since its debut in 1978." [1]
sourceList: Rainbow flag (LGBT movement). (2018, July 12). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Rainbow_flag_(LGBT_movement)&oldid=874834613)
citation.imageSource: Gay flag.svg. (2011, Sep 2). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Gay_flag.svg&oldid=318653423)

citation.text: "Bisexuality is romantic attraction, sexual attraction, or sexual behavior toward both males and females, or romantic or sexual attraction to people of any sex or gender identity; this latter aspect is sometimes alternatively termed pansexuality." [1]
sourceList: Bisexuality. (2017, Dec 20). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bisexuality&oldid=871614738)
citation.imageSource: Bi flag.svg. (2008, Feb 2). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Bi_flag.svg&oldid=322295708)

citation.text: "Asexuality is the lack of sexual attraction to others, or low or absent interest in or desire for sexual activity. It may be considered the lack of a sexual orientation, or one of the variations thereof, alongside heterosexuality, homosexuality and bisexuality. It may also be categorized more widely to include a broad spectrum of asexual sub-identities. Asexuality is distinct from abstention from sexual activity and from celibacy, which are behavioral and generally motivated by factors such as an individual's personal or religious beliefs. Sexual orientation, unlike sexual behavior, is believed to be "enduring". Some asexual people engage in sexual activity despite lacking sexual attraction or a desire for sex, due to a variety of reasons, such as a desire to pleasure themselves or romantic partners, or a desire to have children." [1]
sourceList: Asexuality. (2018, April 9). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Asexuality&oldid=871893138)
citation.imageSource: Asexual flag.svg. (2010, Sep 18). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Asexual_flag.svg&oldid=326396229)
citation.firstAuthoring: bristrek. (2010, Aug 11). Asexual Flag: And the winner is..... [Online discussion group]. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [www.asexuality.org](https://www.asexuality.org/en/topic/53435-asexual-flag-and-the-winner-is/)

citation.text: "Transgender people have a gender identity or gender expression that differs from their assigned sex... Transgender is also an umbrella term: in addition to including people whose gender identity is the opposite of their assigned sex (trans men and trans women), it may include people who are not exclusively masculine or feminine (people who are genderqueer or non-binary, including bigender, pangender, genderfluid, or agender). Other definitions of transgender also include people who belong to a third gender, or else conceptualize transgender people as a third gender." [1]
sourceList: Transgender. (2018, June 14). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Transgender&oldid=874625004)
citation.imageSource: Transgender Pride flag.svg. (2018, April 6). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Transgender_Pride_flag.svg&oldid=295842582)

citation.text: "An agender person... is someone who identifies as having no gender or being without a gender identity. Although this category includes a broad range of identities which do not conform to traditional gender norms, scholar Finn Enke states that people who identify with any of these positions may not necessarily self-identify as transgender. Agender people have no specific set of pronouns; singular they is typically used, but it is not the default." [1]
sourceList: Genderqueer. (2018, July 8). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Genderqueer&oldid=874316981)
citation.imageSource: Agender pride flag.svg. (2015, Feb 6). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Agender_pride_flag.svg&oldid=296272703)
citation.firstAuthoring: transrants. (2014, Feb 19). a more pastel version of my agender/genderless… [Tumblr post]. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [batty.co.vu](http://batty.co.vu/post/77148681532/a-more-pastel-version-of-my-agendergenderless)

citation.text: "Intersex people are born with any of several variations in sex characteristics including chromosomes, gonads, sex hormones, or genitals that, according to the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, "do not fit the typical definitions for male or female bodies". Such variations may involve genital ambiguity, and combinations of chromosomal genotype and sexual phenotype other than XY-male and XX-female." [1]
sourceList: Intersex. (2018, Sep 11). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Intersex&oldid=874876499)
citation.imageSource: Intersex flag.svg. (2013, Dec 20). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Intersex_flag.svg&oldid=295700760)
citation.firstAuthoring: Intersex Human Rights Australia. (2013, July 5). An intersex flag. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [ihra.org.au](https://ihra.org.au/22773/an-intersex-flag/)

citation.text: "Lesbian feminism is a cultural movement and critical perspective, most influential in the 1970s and early 1980s (primarily in North America and Western Europe), that encourages women to direct their energies toward other women rather than men, and often advocates lesbianism as the logical result of feminism. In the words of lesbian feminist Sheila Jeffreys, "Lesbian feminism emerged as a result of two developments: lesbians within the WLM (Women's Liberation Movement) began to create a new, distinctively feminist lesbian politics, and lesbians in the GLF (Gay Liberation Front) left to join up with their sisters". According to Judy Rebick, a leading Canadian journalist and feminist activist, lesbians were and always have been at the heart of the women's movement, while their issues were invisible in the same movement. Lesbian feminism of color emerged as a response to lesbian feminism thought that failed to incorporate the issues of class and race as sources of oppression along with heterosexuality." [1]
sourceList: Lesbian feminism. (2018, Feb 16). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lesbian_feminism&oldid=874775222)
citation.imageSource: Lesbian pride flag.svg. (2018, Jan 22). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Lesbian_pride_flag.svg&oldid=332125792)
citation.firstAuthoring: Campbell, S. (2000, June). Palm Springs Gay and Lesbian Times. based on information from [The Queerstory Files](http://queerstoryfiles.blogspot.com/2012/06/putting-out-sean-campbells-flags.html), but not confirmed independently.

citation.text: "In male gay culture, a bear is often a larger or obese hairier man who projects an image of rugged masculinity. Bears are one of many LGBT communities with events, codes, and a culture-specific identity. However, in San Francisco in the 1970s any hairy man of whatever shape was referred to as a 'bear' until the term was appropriated by larger men and other words had to be used to describe hairy other-shaped men such as otter (slim), cub (young bear on the way), or wolf (hairy, medium build)." [1]
sourceList: Bear (gay culture). (2018, June 20). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bear_(gay_culture)&oldid=875877600)
citation.imageSource: Bear Brotherhood flag.svg. (2007, April 29). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Bear_Brotherhood_flag.svg&oldid=296224792)

citation.text: "Bigender, bi-gender or dual gender is a gender identity that includes any two gender identities and behaviors. Some bigender individuals express two distinct personas, which may be feminine, masculine, agender, androgyne, or other gender identities; others find that they identify as two genders simultaneously. A 1999 survey conducted by the San Francisco Department of Public Health observed that, among the transgender community, less than 3% of those who were assigned male at birth and less than 8% of those who were assigned female at birth identified as bigender." [1] Several sources identify this as an Intersex Pride Flag, claiming that the creator, Natalie Phox, renamed the flag later to clarify the identity it represents. [2], [3]. On this website, it is listed as both a Bigender Pride Flag and an Intersex Pride Flag
sourceList: Bigender. (2018, Feb 28). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bigender&oldid=875947825)

citation.text: "Demisexuality is a sexual orientation in which someone feels sexual attraction only to people with whom they have an emotional bond. Most demisexuals feel sexual attraction rarely compared to the general population, and some have little to no interest in sexual activity." [1]
sourceList: What is Demisexuality?. (n.d.). Demisexuality Resource Center. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [demisexuality.org](http://demisexuality.org/articles/what-is-demisexuality/)
citation.imageSource: Demisexual Flag.svg. (2013 June 22). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Demisexual_Flag.svg&oldid=327397892)

citation.text: "Pansexuality, or omnisexuality, is the sexual, romantic or emotional attraction towards people regardless of their sex or gender identity. Pansexual people may refer to themselves as gender-blind, asserting that gender and sex are not determining factors in their romantic or sexual attraction to others. Pansexuality may be considered a sexual orientation in its own right or a branch of bisexuality, to indicate an alternative sexual identity. Because pansexual people are open to relationships with people who do not identify as strictly men or women, and pansexuality therefore rejects the gender binary, it is often considered a more inclusive term than bisexual. To what extent the term bisexual is inclusive when compared with the term pansexual is debated within the LGBT community, especially the bisexual community." [1]
sourceList: Pansexuality. (2017, Sep 20). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pansexuality&oldid=868395019)
citation.imageSource: Pansexuality flag.svg. (2013, Jul 14). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Pansexuality_flag.svg&oldid=295842422)

citation.text: "A lipstick lesbian is slang for a lesbian who exhibits a greater amount of feminine gender attributes relative to other gender expressions, such as wearing make-up (thus, lipstick), wearing dresses or skirts and having other characteristics associated with feminine women. In popular usage, the term lipstick lesbian is also used to characterize the feminine gender expression of bisexual women who are romantically or sexually interested in other women, or to the broader topic of female-female sexual activity among feminine women." [1]
sourceList: Lipstick lesbian. (2017, Mar 14). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lipstick_lesbian&oldid=865976807)

citation.text: "A lesbian is a homosexual woman. The word lesbian is also used for women in relation to their sexual identity or sexual behavior regardless of sexual orientation, or as an adjective to characterize or associate nouns with female homosexuality or same-sex attraction." [1]
sourceList: Lesbian. (2018, Jul 20). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lesbian&oldid=875106427)
citation.imageSource: Lesbian Pride rainbow flag.svg. (2011, Jun 29). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Lesbian_Pride_rainbow_flag.svg&oldid=329223630)

citation.text: "Transgender people have a gender identity or gender expression that differs from their assigned sex... Transgender is also an umbrella term: in addition to including people whose gender identity is the opposite of their assigned sex (trans men and trans women), it may include people who are not exclusively masculine or feminine (people who are genderqueer or non-binary, including bigender, pangender, genderfluid, or agender). Other definitions of transgender also include people who belong to a third gender, or else conceptualize transgender people as a third gender." [1]
sourceList: Transgender. (2018, June 14). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Transgender&oldid=874625004)
citation.imageSource: Israeli Transgender Flag.svg. (2017, Jul 12). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Israeli_Transgender_Flag.svg&oldid=297332168)

citation.text: "Polysexuality is sexual attraction to multiple, but not all, genders. A polysexual person is one "encompassing or characterized by many different kinds of sexuality." Authors Linda Garnets and Douglas Kimmel state that polysexual is a sexual identity "used by people who recognize that the term bisexual reifies the gender dichotomy that underlies the distinction between heterosexuality and homosexuality, implying that bisexuality is nothing more than a hybrid combination of these gender and sexual dichotomies". However, bisexual people and scholars may object to the notion that bisexuality means sexual attraction to only two genders, arguing that since bisexual is not simply about attraction to two sexes and encompasses attraction to different genders as well, it includes attraction to more than two genders." [1]
sourceList: Polysexuality. (2018, Jan 14). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Polysexuality&oldid=874707552)
citation.imageSource: Polysexuality flag.svg. (2015, Feb 6). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Polysexuality_flag.svg&oldid=296225063)

citation.text: "Gay is a term that primarily refers to a homosexual person or the trait of being homosexual. The term was originally used to mean "carefree", "cheerful", or "bright and showy". The term's use as a reference to homosexuality may date as early as the late 19th century, but its use gradually increased in the mid-20th century. In modern English, gay has come to be used as an adjective, and as a noun, referring to the community, practices and cultures associated with homosexuality. In the 1960s, gay became the word favored by homosexual men to describe their sexual orientation. By the end of the 20th century, the word gay was recommended by major LGBT groups and style guides to describe people attracted to members of the same sex." [1]
sourceList: Gay. (2018, Apr 16). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gay&oldid=876173653)
citation.imageSource: Gay Pride flag of the United Kingdom.svg. (2013, Apr 20). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Gay_Pride_flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg&oldid=332170224)

citation.text: "An aromantic person is an individual who does not experience romantic love or attraction, although this does not preclude them from feeling other forms of love or attraction, such as platonic love. Keep in mind, aromanticisim is a spectrum, so people may experience different forms of attraction, but still consider themselves to be aromantic." [1]
sourceList: Aromantic. (2018, July 9). In Aromantics Wiki. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [aromantic.wikia.com](http://aromantic.wikia.com/wiki/Aromantic?oldid=7321)

flags.name: Trans Queer PoC New Pride Flag

citation.text: "This new Pride flag highlights the beginning of the LGBTQIA+ Pride Movement in the US led by Black Trans women/MaGe like Marsha P. Johnson and Ms Major, as well as Trans PoC like Sylvia Rivera and Victoria Cruz. The flags center Trans and Queer Black, Brown, and Indigenous people, who endure disproportionate murder rates and other transphobic targeting." [1]
sourceList: About the Flag - New Pride Flag. (n.d.). New Pride Flag. Retrieved December 26, 2019, from [newprideflag.com/about](https://www.newprideflag.com/about/)

citation.text: "When the Pride flag was recreated in 2017 and 2018 to include both black/brown stripes, as well as the trans stripes, I wanted to see if there could be more emphasis in the design of the flag to elevate its message. This new design forces the viewer to reflect on their own feelings towards the original Pride flag and its meaning as well as the differing opinions on who that flag really represents, while also bringing into clear focus the current needs within our community. You can’t avoid the message as it is right there in front of you." [1]
sourceList: Progress Initiative. (n.d.).  Daniel Quasar. Retrieved December 13, 2020, from [quasar.digital](https://progress.gay/)
citation.imageSource: "Progress" Design Terms of Use. (n.d.).  Daniel Quasar. Retrieved December 13, 2020, from [quasar.digital](https://progress.gay/pages/terms-of-use)

citation.text: "Demiromantic is a romantic orientation on the aromantic spectrum defined as someone who does not experience romantic attraction until they have formed a deep emotional connection with someone." [1]
sourceList: Demiromantic. (2018, July 1). In LGBTA Wiki. Retrieved June 26, 2020, from [lgbta.wikia.org](https://lgbta.wikia.org/wiki/Demiromantic?oldid=113)

citation.text: A gender creative person is "a person whose conception of their gender intrinsically differs from the prevailing social norms". "The gender creative pride flag is constructed of two exterior lavender fields in opposition, a composite of the pink and blue fields found in the transgender pride flag and an interior white field one-fifth the proportion to the remainder. Lavender represents the blurring of binary gender norms whereas white represents freedom of gender expression." [1]
sourceList: Gender Creative Pride. (2015, July 19). Today I am proposing a pride flag and an icon for gender nonconforming people, and I am recommending the formation [Image attached] [Status update]. Facebook. [facebook.com](https://www.facebook.com/gendercreativepride/photos/a.1082412285144180/1086036191448456/)

citation.text: "I came up with the idea for the transgender flag a few years ago. At the time I did not know of any other flag designs. The design was created for TG pride. another reson I made the flag is that most cross dressers are not gay. If they use the rainbow flag people will think they are gay. The colors on the flag are from top to bottom. Pink, light purple, medium purple, dark purple, and blue. The pink and the blue represent male and female. The 3 purple stripes represent the diversity of the TG community as well as genders other than male and female." [1]
sourceList: Jennifer. (n.d.). Transgender Flag info. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [web.archive.org](https://web.archive.org/web/20030713171303/http://www.transflag.org/info.html)

citation.text: "Intersex people are born with any of several variations in sex characteristics including chromosomes, gonads, sex hormones, or genitals that, according to the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, "do not fit the typical definitions for male or female bodies". Such variations may involve genital ambiguity, and combinations of chromosomal genotype and sexual phenotype other than XY-male and XX-female." [1] While the Wikimedia source for this flag identifies this as a Bigender Pride Flag, other sources identify this as an Intersex Pride Flag, claiming that the creator, Natalie Phox, renamed the flag later to clarify the identity it represents. [2], [3]. On this website, it is listed as both a Bigender Pride Flag and an Intersex Pride Flag.
sourceList: Intersex. (2018, Sep 11). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 24, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Intersex&oldid=874876499)

TRANSPRIDE. (2010, Nov 10). I was curious where the flag came from because… [Tumblr post]. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [transpride.tumblr.com](https://transpride.tumblr.com/post/1531378118)
citation.imageSource: Bigender pride flag.svg. (2015, Feb 22). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Bigender_pride_flag.svg&oldid=323639719)

citation.text: "I was talking w/ intersex folx who're also trans. They said there wasn't a trans-intersex flag, so I made one! The transgender pride flag has been inserted within the circle of the intersex pride flag to signify the inner identities of intersex people who do not identify with the gender their doctors and/or parents assigned them at birth." [1]
sourceList: Jesse Bananasaurus. (2017, July 6). The trans-intersex flag I created. I was talking w/ intersex folx who're also trans. They said there wasn't a [Image attached] [Status update]. Facebook. [facebook.com](https://www.facebook.com/JesseBananasaurus/photos/292569341213530)
citation.imageSource: Trans intersex pride flag.svg (2021, Jan 16). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Trans_intersex_pride_flag.svg)

citation.text: "An agender person... is someone who identifies as having no gender or being without a gender identity. Although this category includes a broad range of identities which do not conform to traditional gender norms, scholar Finn Enke states that people who identify with any of these positions may not necessarily self-identify as transgender. Agender people have no specific set of pronouns; singular they is typically used, but it is not the default." [1] According to uncited text on Gender Wiki, it was "[c]reated 2014 by Rumpus Parable... Black is to indicate a distinct identity in those without gender. The color black for agender persons is chosen for its correspondence with black being the total absence of color in the light spectrum. White acknowledges the historical use as an all-inclusive color for anyone who is non-binary in sex and/or gender and the identity color of black to be placed against to indicate its specific grouping within that traditionally generalized non-binary color." [2]
sourceList: Genderqueer. (2018, July 8). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Genderqueer&oldid=874316981)
Pride Flags. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Pride_Flags)
citation.imageSource: Pride Flags. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Pride_Flags)

citation.text: "An agender person... is someone who identifies as having no gender or being without a gender identity. Although this category includes a broad range of identities which do not conform to traditional gender norms, scholar Finn Enke states that people who identify with any of these positions may not necessarily self-identify as transgender. Agender people have no specific set of pronouns; singular they is typically used, but it is not the default." [1] "The four-stripe agender flag is an homage to the original, widely-used seven-stripe agender flag created by Salem in 2014... They're similar in color scheme (black, gray, white, green). However, the new flag has a deliberately higher-contrast design with fewer stripes and emphasizes solidarity of agender people who may also be lesbian, gay, bi, nonbinary, trans, ace, etc. by representing agenderness in one stripe. No matter what else we are, all agender people are wholly equally agender." [2]
sourceList: Genderqueer. (2018, July 8). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Genderqueer&oldid=874316981)
Why make a new flag?. (n.d). agender.info. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [agender.info](https://agender.info/#flag)
citation.imageSource: Agender pride flag agender info.svg. (2021, Jan 16). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Agender_pride_flag_agender_info.svg)
citation.firstAuthoring: Why make a new flag?. (n.d). agender.info. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [agender.info](https://agender.info/#flag)

citation.text: "Pangender refers to a vast and diverse multiplicity of genders in the same individual that can infinitely extend, being always within the person's own culture and life experience. This experience can be either simultaneously or over time. Pangender is a multigender that is very expansive and not very specific, meaning that there are so many genders that it’s difficult or impossible to list all of them. There is no maximum limit to the amount of genders. Being pangender is feeling an entire infinite gender spectrum that is possible for an individual to have. The pangender experience can go beyond the current knowledge of genders. The Greek prefix "pan" refers to "everything" or "all". Therefore, pangender means "having all genders it’s possible to have" and other similar definitions." [1]
sourceList: pangendering. (2015, Jan 8). Possible pangender pride flags… [Tumblr post]. Retrieved January 1, 2021, from [pangendering.tumblr.com](https://pangendering.tumblr.com/post/109400686126/possible-pangender-pride-flags)
citation.imageSource: pangendering. (2015, Jan 8). Possible pangender pride flags… [Tumblr post]. Retrieved January 1, 2021, from [pangendering.tumblr.com](https://pangendering.tumblr.com/post/109400686126/possible-pangender-pride-flags)
citation.firstAuthoring: pangendering. (2015, Jan 8). Possible pangender pride flags… [Tumblr post]. Retrieved January 1, 2021, from [pangendering.tumblr.com](https://pangendering.tumblr.com/post/109400686126/possible-pangender-pride-flags)

citation.text: "Pocket gender is a series of gender identities that are used by either one person or a small group of people." [1] "The pink and blue represent masculinity and feminity. They are shaped in (semi) triangles to represent the varying amounts of masculinity and feminity. The purple represents a mix of both (feminity and masculinity and/or genderlessness), the black represents a lack of either or a mix including some form of genderlessness, and the orange represents Maverique, the separation of any gender including genderlessness." [2]
sourceList: Pocket Genders. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 16, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Pocket_Gender)

citation.text: "As IngenDerism is about the unity of humanity, rather than separating people by their differences, a white flag is used, as all colours are merely part of white." [1]

citation.text: "Bigender, bi-gender or dual gender is a gender identity that includes any two gender identities and behaviors. Some bigender individuals express two distinct personas, which may be feminine, masculine, agender, androgyne, or other gender identities; others find that they identify as two genders simultaneously. A 1999 survey conducted by the San Francisco Department of Public Health observed that, among the transgender community, less than 3% of those who were assigned male at birth and less than 8% of those who were assigned female at birth identified as bigender." [1]
sourceList: Bigender. (2018, Feb 28). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 1, 2019, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bigender&oldid=875947825)
citation.imageSource: Pride Flags. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Pride_Flags)

citation.text: "Demigender is a gender identity of a person identifying partially or mostly with one gender and at the same time with another gender. There are several subcategories of the identity. A demi-boy or demi-man, for example, identifies at least partially with being a boy or a man, no matter the sex and gender they were assigned at birth, while other parts of their identity might be assigned to other genders, genderfluid or no other gender (agender). A demiflux person feels that the stable part of their identity is non-binary." [1]
sourceList: Non-binary gender. (2021, Jan 5). In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-binary_gender#Definitions_and_identity)
citation.imageSource: Pride Flags. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Pride_Flags)

A demi-boy or demi-man, for example, identifies at least partially with being a boy or a man, no matter the sex and gender they were assigned at birth, while other parts of their identity might be assigned to other genders, genderfluid or no other gender (agender). A demiflux person feels that the stable part of their identity is non-binary." [1]

citation.text: "Neutrois is a non-binary gender identity which is often associated with a "neutral" or "null" gender. It may also be associated with genderlessness, and shares many similarities with agender - people who consider themselves neutrally gendered or genderless, but some may identify as both, while others may prefer one term or the other. " [1]
sourceList: Neutrois. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Neutroiss)
citation.imageSource: Neutrois Flag.svg. (2018, April 7). In Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved December 17, 2020, from [commons.wikimedia.org](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Neutrois_Flag.svg)

citation.text: "Genderqueer, also known as non-binary, is a catch-all category for gender identities that are not exclusively masculine or feminine-identities which are outside the gender binary and cisnormativity. Genderqueer people may express a combination of masculinity and femininity, or neither, in their gender expression." [1]
sourceList: Genderqueer. (2018, July 8). In Wikipedia. Retrieved December 23, 2018, from [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Genderqueer&oldid=874316981)

citation.text: "Genderflux is an umbrella term for gender identities in which the gender or one’s perception of the gender’s intensity varies over time. It can be seen as a form of genderfluid on a spectrum from agender to one or more other gender identities. Genderflux people may also identify as nonbinary, genderqueer and/or transgender." [1]
sourceList: Genderflux. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Genderflux)

citation.text: Does are "people whose identity or expression is feminine, without necessarily being women or femmes." [1]

citation.text: "Littlefluid describes a gender identity where your gender changes with switching from a normal headspace to littlespace. Littlefluid people may use alternating pronouns and names." [1]
sourceList: Littlefluid. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Littlefluid)
citation.imageSource: Littlefluid. (n.d). In Gender Wiki. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [gender.wikia.org](https://gender.wikia.org/wiki/Littlefluid)

citation.text: "A gender that is both a nonbinary gender (such as maverique) and agender/no gender. You can be a nonbinary gender and agender/no gender at the same time, go between them, or fluctuate between feeling a gender and not feeling gender. Emphasizes being a nonbinary gender. Spelled nxnbinary with an X instead of an O as if you’re crossing out that you’re a gender. Kinda similar to demigender (where agender/no gender is the non-gendered part), agenderflux (with fluctuations between agender and a gender), or being genderfluid between agender/no gender and a nonbinary gender. " [1]
sourceList: Nxnbinary (2). (2017, Jan 18). pride-flags. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [deviantart.com](https://www.deviantart.com/pride-flags/art/Nxnbinary-2-657852683)

citation.text: "Gxrl (pronounced like girl-x) [is] a gender that is both girl and agender/no gender. You can be a girl and agender/no gender at the same time, go between them, or fluctuate between feeling female and not feeling gender. Emphasizes being female. Spelled gxrl with an X instead of an I as if you’re crossing out that you’re a girl. Kinda similar to demigirl (where agender/no gender is the non-girl part), agenderflux (with fluctuations between agender and female), or being genderfluid between agender/no gender and female. Can be used as transgxrl if you chose to, but only if you’re amab (similar to trans feminine being exclusively for amab trans people). Coined by www.deviantart.com/ayumi-hino in conjunction with sadghostbxy.tumblr.com coining bxy." [1]
sourceList: Gxrl. (2017, Jan 17). pride-flags. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [deviantart.com](https://www.deviantart.com/pride-flags/art/Gxrl-657852708)
citation.imageSource: Gxrl. (2017, Jan 17). pride-flags. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [deviantart.com](https://www.deviantart.com/pride-flags/art/Gxrl-657852708)
citation.firstAuthoring: Gxrl. (2017, Jan 17). pride-flags. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [deviantart.com](https://www.deviantart.com/pride-flags/art/Gxrl-657852708)

citation.text: "Bxy (pronounced like boy) [is] [a] gender that is both boy and agender/no gender. You can be a boy and agender/no gender at the same time, go between them, or fluctuate between feeling male and not feeling gender. Emphasizes being male. Spelled bxy with an X instead of an O as if you’re crossing out that you’re a boy. Kinda similar to demiboy (where agender/no gender is the non-boy part), agenderflux (with fluctuations between agender and male), or being genderfluid between agender/no gender and male. Can be used as trans bxy if you chose to, but only if you’re afab (similar to trans masculine being exclusively for afab trans people)." [1]
sourceList: Bxy. (2017, Jan 17). pride-flags. Retrieved January 17, 2021, from [deviantart.com](https://www.deviantart.com/pride-flags/art/Bxy-657852717)
